subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Re: More experiments.
author: Zack Widup
full_text:
Wow, excellent!  I was kind of leading into that - possibly it could be 
used in conjunction with Frank's box or just by itself on an 
investigation.

I've been fascinated with "radionics", "psychotronics", "psi machines", 
or whatever you want to call them, for decades. There's some interesting 
stuff in the book "The Excalibur Briefing" by Thomas E. Bearden.

(Sorry about the late response, I've been terribly busy and I'm getting 
caught up on some e-mail).

Zack

On Tue, 17 Jul 2007, psi_research wrote:

> Hi Zack, I have a new radionics kit based on the original Hieronymus
> machine. It made from Bakelite, even the stick plate is. I still need
> to wire it up so I just placed the components on the still unassembled
> board and uploaded a pic in my photo album on this forum. The stick
> plate is also made of Bakelite but I placed a small plastic square
> where the stick pad goes. My crazy plane was to adapt it to the tuning
> mechanism of Frank's Box to allow an intuitive tactile feedback
> interface so I could try to find the frequencies where spirits contact
> us.
>
> Sort of like the manual linear sweep but with a stick pad added. These
> 3 dial machines are still available from Bill Jensen out of Knoxville
> TN who makes them to original spec except with modern internal
> circuitry. -Bill Murphy
>
> --- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, Zack Widup <w9sz@...> wrote:
>>
>> On Mon, 16 Jul 2007, Frank Sumption wrote:
>>
>>> This time I made a small plastic echo box. I tried plastic years
> ago, and it
>>> didn't work, this time it seems to. The injection speaker accounts
> for the
>>> weaker voices I think, since it's an ear bud, and is 32 ohm,
> normal speakers
>>> are 8 ohms. More voices are in my folder.
>>>
>>
>> There are so many different types of plastics with so many different
>> characteristics ... ABS plastic, PVC, Delrin, acrylic, PTFE (teflon),
>> Cyrolon ZX ...
>>
>> It might be interesting to experiment with different types and see what
>> works the best.
>>
>> Anyone here ever build a Hieronymus machine?  I understand teflon (or
>> fiberglass-teflon PC board material) works incredibly well for the
>> "stick" sensor plate.
>>
>> Zack
>>
